text: Good story more fun and interactive than the first
It’s not bad, but I can’t believe that it has better ratings than the first.

If the first Angry Birds film felt like a messy attempt to cash in on a wildly popular video game, the sequel is the movie that redeemed this franchise. Where the original struggled to balance humor, story, and character, The Angry Birds Movie 2 embraces its silliness with a sharper comedic edge and a much more enjoyable story.

This time around, the film builds on the world established in the first movie but does so with better pacing, smarter jokes, and more heart. The characters don’t just feel like throwaway game mascots — they feel lively, important, and genuinely fun to watch. The writing allows them to grow while still leaning into their quirks, and the humor lands far more consistently.

One of the smartest choices was keeping the same cast intact. Even though the first film wasn’t a hit with audiences, the familiar voices help carry this one and make it feel like a proper continuation. The director also deserves credit for pulling everything together — from the animation to the comedic timing — in a way that breathes new life into the Angry Birds on the big screen.

What surprised me most was how much the movie restores faith in the franchise. It reminds you why people loved the characters in the first place — not just because of the game or the merchandise, but because they can be genuinely entertaining in the right story. And yes, even the pigs, while still the villains, get some of the funniest and most memorable moments.

Overall, The Angry Birds Movie 2 is a colorful, clever, and much-improved sequel that proves sometimes the second chance is worth taking. If you wrote off the first film, give this one a try — it’s the movie that finally made Angry Birds soar on the big screen.

this movie actually surprised the heck out of me. Like, seriously, my jaw was on the floor a couple of times. It's not just "not bad"; it's actually a pretty good sequel, and arguably even better than the first one. Who saw that coming? Not me!

First off, the animation got a serious glow-up. Everything looks sharper, more vibrant, and the character designs feel more expressive. They really stepped up their game visually, and it makes a huge difference. The world feels more fleshed out, and the action sequences are more dynamic and fun to watch. It's clear they put more effort into making it look good, and it pays off.

Then there's the humor. This is where it really shines. The jokes are genuinely clever and land more often than not. They leaned into the absurdity, and there's a lot of physical comedy that had me laughing out loud. What's even better is that they threw in some jokes that clearly went over the heads of the little ones but resonated with the adults in the room. It felt like they finally figured out how to make a movie that appeals to both kids and parents without dumbing it down too much. The team-up dynamic between the birds and the pigs, forced by a new threat, opens up a lot of hilarious situations and banter.

The story, while still being a kids' movie plot, felt more engaging. The concept of sworn enemies having to work together creates a lot of great comedic moments and even some unexpected character development. It keeps things moving at a good pace, and it never feels like it's dragging. They introduce new characters that are actually pretty funny and add to the dynamic, instead of just being tacked on.
